title: Triangle Foundations
description: Classify triangles by sides and angles using dual classification, apply the Triangle Angle Sum Theorem and Exterior Angle Theorem to find missing measures algebraically, and use the Triangle Inequality Theorem to determine valid side lengths.
goals: Classify triangles by sides (scalene, isosceles, equilateral) and by angles (acute, right, obtuse)
Apply the Triangle Angle Sum Theorem to find missing angle measures
Use the Exterior Angle Theorem to find angle measures
Apply the Triangle Inequality Theorem to determine valid triangle side lengths
Set up and solve algebraic equations involving triangle angle relationships
instructionalStrategy: Use dual classification—a triangle can be described by BOTH its sides and angles (e.g., 'acute isosceles').
For Triangle Angle Sum, tearing the corners of a paper triangle and arranging them on a straight line is a powerful visual proof.
The Exterior Angle Theorem is a direct consequence of the Angle Sum Theorem—connect them explicitly.
For Triangle Inequality, have students try building triangles with different stick lengths to discover the rule physically.
Build from classification (recognizing types) to theorem application (algebraic) to inequality reasoning (range problems).

scaffold.title: Classifying Triangles: By Sides and By Angles
scaffold.content:
A triangle is a polygon with three sides and three angles. We classify triangles in two ways:

**By sides:**
• **Scalene** — no sides congruent
• **Isosceles** — at least two sides congruent
• **Equilateral** — all three sides congruent

**By angles:**
• **Acute** — all angles less than 90°
• **Right** — one angle exactly 90°
• **Obtuse** — one angle greater than 90°
• **Equiangular** — all angles equal (60° each)

Every triangle gets a DUAL classification—one from each category.
scaffold.initialPrompt: A triangle has sides measuring 5 cm, 5 cm, and 8 cm. How would you classify it by its sides? Can you guess what type it might be by its angles?

scaffold.title: I-Do: Triangle Classification

examples.problem: A triangle has angles measuring 40°, 60°, and 80°. Classify it by its angles and explain why.
examples.solution:
Let's check each angle:
• 40° < 90° ✓
• 60° < 90° ✓
• 80° < 90° ✓

Since ALL three angles are less than 90°, this is an **acute triangle**.

Also notice: 40° + 60° + 80° = 180°. That's not a coincidence—it's the **Triangle Angle Sum Theorem**: the interior angles of ANY triangle always add up to exactly 180°.

examples.problem: A triangle has sides 7 cm, 7 cm, and 7 cm, with all angles measuring 60°. Give its full dual classification.
examples.solution:
**By sides:** All three sides are congruent (7 = 7 = 7), so it's **equilateral**.
**By angles:** All three angles are 60° (all less than 90° and all equal), so it's **equiangular** (also acute).

**Dual classification: equilateral equiangular triangle.**

Key insight: every equilateral triangle is also equiangular, and vice versa. This is because equal sides always produce equal opposite angles.

examples.problem: A triangle has sides 3, 4, and 5 with a right angle opposite the longest side. Give its full dual classification.
examples.solution:
**By sides:** 3 ≠ 4 ≠ 5 (no sides congruent), so it's **scalene**.
**By angles:** One angle is exactly 90°, so it's a **right triangle**.

**Dual classification: right scalene triangle.**

Fun fact: 3-4-5 is the most famous Pythagorean triple. We'll study that in depth later!

scaffold.initialPrompt: What if I changed the 80° angle to a 90° angle? What would the third angle have to be, and how would the classification change?

scaffold.title: Triangle Angle Sum and Exterior Angle Theorems
scaffold.content:
The **Triangle Angle Sum Theorem** states that the sum of the three interior angles of any triangle is always 180°. This means if you know two angles, you can always find the third.

The **Exterior Angle Theorem** is related: an exterior angle of a triangle equals the sum of the two non-adjacent interior angles (called remote interior angles). If an exterior angle is at vertex C, then the exterior angle = angle A + angle B.

Why does this work? The interior angle at C plus the exterior angle = 180° (linear pair). But angle A + angle B + angle C = 180° too. So the exterior angle = angle A + angle B.
scaffold.initialPrompt: Why do you think the exterior angle equals the sum of the two remote interior angles? Can you connect this to the Angle Sum Theorem and the idea that a straight angle is 180°?

scaffold.title: I-Do: Angle Sum and Exterior Angle Theorem

examples.problem: In triangle ABC, angle A = 45° and angle B = 72°. Find angle C and the exterior angle at vertex C.
examples.solution:
**Finding angle C:**
Angle A + Angle B + Angle C = 180°
45° + 72° + Angle C = 180°
117° + Angle C = 180°
Angle C = 63°

**Finding the exterior angle at C:**
Method 1 (Exterior Angle Theorem): Exterior angle = Angle A + Angle B = 45° + 72° = 117°
Method 2 (Linear pair): Exterior angle + Angle C = 180°, so Exterior angle = 180° - 63° = 117° ✓

Both methods give 117°, confirming the Exterior Angle Theorem works!

examples.problem: The angles of a triangle are (2x + 5)°, (3x - 10)°, and (x + 35)°. Find x and all three angle measures.
examples.solution:
Using Triangle Angle Sum:
(2x + 5) + (3x - 10) + (x + 35) = 180
6x + 30 = 180
6x = 150
x = 25

Angle measures:
• 2(25) + 5 = 55°
• 3(25) - 10 = 65°
• 25 + 35 = 60°

Check: 55 + 65 + 60 = 180° ✓

Classification: all angles < 90°, so this is an acute triangle.

examples.problem: An exterior angle of a triangle measures (5x + 15)°. The two remote interior angles are (2x + 10)° and (x + 25)°. Find x and all angle measures.
examples.solution:
By the Exterior Angle Theorem:
Exterior = sum of remote interiors
5x + 15 = (2x + 10) + (x + 25)
5x + 15 = 3x + 35
2x = 20
x = 10

Remote interiors: 2(10) + 10 = 30° and 10 + 25 = 35°
Exterior angle: 5(10) + 15 = 65°
Check: 30 + 35 = 65° ✓

The interior angle adjacent to the exterior: 180° - 65° = 115°
Verify angle sum: 30 + 35 + 115 = 180° ✓

scaffold.initialPrompt: Notice that the exterior angle (117°) is larger than either remote interior angle alone. Will this always be true? Why?

scaffold.title: We-Do: Angle Sum and Exterior Angles

problems.question: A triangle has angles measuring (2x + 10)°, (3x)°, and (x + 20)°. Find x and all three angle measures.
hints: Use the Triangle Angle Sum Theorem: all three angles sum to 180°.
Set up: (2x + 10) + (3x) + (x + 20) = 180. Combine like terms: 6x + 30 = 180.
Solve: 6x = 150, so x = 25. Then substitute back to find each angle.

problems.question: An exterior angle of a triangle measures 130°. One of the remote interior angles is 55°. Find the other remote interior angle and the interior angle adjacent to the exterior angle.
hints: The Exterior Angle Theorem says: exterior angle = sum of the two remote interior angles.
So 130° = 55° + other remote interior. That gives 75°.
The interior angle adjacent to the exterior angle forms a linear pair: 180° - 130° = 50°.

problems.question: An isosceles triangle has a vertex angle of 50°. Find the base angles and classify the triangle by its angles.
hints: In an isosceles triangle, the base angles are congruent (equal).
Since all angles (50°, 65°, 65°) are less than 90°, it's acute.

scaffold.title: The Triangle Inequality Theorem
scaffold.content:
The **Triangle Inequality Theorem** states that the sum of ANY two sides of a triangle must be greater than the third side. In other words, for sides a, b, and c:
• a + b > c
• a + c > b
• b + c > a

All three inequalities must be true. If even ONE fails, the three lengths cannot form a triangle. A quick shortcut: add the two shortest sides—if that sum is greater than the longest side, the triangle is valid.

**Finding a range:** If two sides are known (say a and b), the third side x must satisfy:
|a - b| < x < a + b
(The difference < third side < the sum)
scaffold.initialPrompt: Can you form a triangle with sides 3, 4, and 8? What about 3, 4, and 5? Try the shortcut with the two shortest sides.

scaffold.title: I-Do: Triangle Inequality Theorem

examples.problem: Can the lengths 6, 9, and 14 form a triangle?
examples.solution:
Shortcut: add the two shortest sides and compare to the longest.
6 + 9 = 15
Is 15 > 14? **Yes!**

Since the sum of the two shortest sides exceeds the longest side, these lengths **can** form a triangle.

examples.problem: Can the lengths 2, 3, and 6 form a triangle?
examples.solution:
Shortcut: add the two shortest sides.
2 + 3 = 5
Is 5 > 6? **No!**

The two shorter sides together (5) are not enough to reach past the longest side (6). These lengths **cannot** form a triangle. Imagine it: the two short sticks laid end to end are still shorter than the long stick—they can't connect to form a closed shape.

examples.problem: Two sides of a triangle are 8 and 13. What is the range of possible values for the third side?
examples.solution:
The third side x must satisfy:
|13 - 8| < x < 13 + 8
5 < x < 21

So the third side must be **greater than 5 and less than 21**.

Why? If x ≤ 5, the two sides (x and 8) can't exceed 13. If x ≥ 21, the two sides (8 and 13) can't exceed x.

scaffold.initialPrompt: For the range problem, why can't the third side be exactly 5 or exactly 21?

scaffold.title: We-Do: Triangle Inequality Practice

problems.question: Can the lengths 7, 10, and 15 form a triangle?
hints: Use the Triangle Inequality: check if the sum of the two shortest sides is greater than the longest side.
7 + 10 = 17. Is 17 > 15? Yes! So these can form a triangle.

problems.question: Two sides of a triangle measure 5 and 12. What is the range of possible values for the third side?
hints: The third side must be less than the sum: x < 5 + 12 = 17.
The third side must be greater than the difference: x > 12 - 5 = 7.
Range: 7 < x < 17.
